refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The gtk.Entry widget is a single line text entry widget. A fairly large set of key bindings are supported by default. If the entered text is longer than the allocation of the widget, the widget will scroll so that the cursor position is visible.

When using an entry for passwords and other sensitive information, it can be put into "password mode" using gtk.Entry.set_visibility(). In this mode, entered text is displayed using a 'invisible' character. By default, GTK+ picks the best invisible character that is available in the current font, but it can be changed with gtk.Entry.set_invisible_char(). Since 2.16, GTK+ displays a warning when Caps Lock or input methods might interfere with entering text in a password entry. The warning can be turned off with the "caps-lock-warning" property.

Since 2.16, gtk.Entry has the ability to display progress or activity information behind the text. To make an entry display such information, use gtk.Entry.set_progress_fraction() or gtk.Entry.set_progress_pulse_step().

Additionally, gtk.Entry can show icons at either side of the entry. These icons can be activatable by clicking, can be set up as drag source and can have tooltips. To add an icon, use gtk.Entry.set_icon_from_gicon() or one of the various other functions that set an icon from a stock id, an icon name or a pixbuf. To trigger an action when the user clicks an icon, connect to the "icon-press" signal. To allow DND operations from an icon, use gtk.Entry.set_icon_drag_source(). To set a tooltip on an icon, use gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_text() or the corresponding function for markup.

Note that functionality or information that is only available by clicking on an icon in an entry may not be accessible at all to users which are not able to use a mouse or other pointing device. It is therefore recommended that any such functionality should also be available by other means, e.g. via the context menu of the entry.

refsect1.title: Constructor

refsect1.para: Creates a new gtk.Entry widget with the maximum length specified by max.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_visibility

listitem.simpara: If False the contents are obscured using the "invisible-char"

refsect2.para: The set_visibility() method sets the "visibility" property to the value of visible. If visible is True the contents of the entry are displayed as plain text. If visible is False, the contents are obscured by replacing the characters with the invisible character (specified by the "invisible-char" property). The characters will also be obscured when the text in the entry widget is copied elsewhere. The default invisible char is the asterisk '*', but it can be changed with set_invisible_char().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_visibility

listitem.simpara: True if the text is currently visible

refsect2.para: The get_visibility() method retrieves the value of the "visibility" property that determines whether the text in entry is visible. See set_visibility().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_invisible_char

listitem.simpara: a Unicode character

refsect2.para: The set_invisible_char() method sets the "invisible-char" property with the value of ch. The "invisible-char" is the character to use in place of the actual text when set_visibility() has been called to set text visibility to False. i.e. this is the character used in "password mode" to show the user how many characters have been typed. The default invisible character is an asterisk ('*'). If you set the invisible character to 0, then the user will get no feedback at all; there will be no text on the screen as they type.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_invisible_char

listitem.simpara: the current invisible char, or 0, if the entry does not show invisible text at all.

refsect2.para: The get_invisible_char() method retrieves the value of the "invisible-char" property. The "invisible-char" is the character displayed in place of the real characters for entries with visibility set to False. See set_invisible_char().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.unset_invisible_char

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The unset_invisible_char() method unsets the invisible char previously set with set_invisible_char() so that the default invisible char is used again.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_has_frame

listitem.simpara: If True the entry is displayed with a beveled frame around it.

refsect2.para: The set_has_frame() method sets the "has-frame" property to the value of setting. If setting is True the entry is displayed with a beveled frame around it.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_has_frame

listitem.simpara: whether the entry has a beveled frame

refsect2.para: The get_has_frame() method gets the value of the "has-frame" property. If "has-frame" is True the entry will be displayed with a beveled frame around it.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_max_length

listitem.simpara: the maximum length of the entry, or 0 for no maximum. (other than the maximum length of entries.) The value passed in will be clamped to the range 0-65536.

refsect2.para: The set_max_length() method sets the "max-length" property to the value of max. The "max-length" property sets the maximum allowed length of the contents of the widget. If the current contents are longer than the given length, then they will be truncated to fit. If max is 0 then there is no maximum length (other than 65536).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_max_length

listitem.simpara: the maximum allowed number of characters in gtk.Entry, or 0 if there is no maximum.

refsect2.para: The get_max_length() method retrieves the value of the "max-length" property that specifies the maximum allowed length of the text in the entry. See set_max_length().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_activates_default

listitem.simpara: If True activate the window's default widget on an Enter key press

refsect2.para: The set_activates_default() method sets the "activates-default" property to the value of setting. If setting is True, pressing the Enter key in the entry will activate the default widget for the window containing the entry. This usually means that the dialog box containing the entry will be closed, since the default widget is usually one of the dialog buttons.
(For experts: if setting is True, the entry calls gtk.Window.activate_default() on the window containing the entry, in the default handler for the "activate" signal.)

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_activates_default

listitem.simpara: True if the entry will activate the default widget

refsect2.para: The get_activates_default() method retrieves the value of the "activates-default" property which is set by set_activates_default(). If "activates-default" is True pressing the Enter key in the entry will activate the default widget for the window containing the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_width_chars

listitem.simpara: width in chars

refsect2.para: The set_width_chars() method sets the "width-chars" property to the value of n_char. Setting the "width-chars" property changes the size request of the entry to be about the right size for n_chars characters. Note that it only changes the size request, the size can still be affected by how you pack the widget into containers. If n_chars is -1, the size reverts to the default entry size.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_width_chars

listitem.simpara: number of chars to request space for, or negative if unset

refsect2.para: The get_width_chars() method gets the value of the "width-chars" property which is set by the set_width_chars() method.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_text

listitem.simpara: a string to use as the new contents of the entry

refsect2.para: The set_text() method sets the "text" property to the value of text. The string in text replaces the current contents of the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_text

listitem.simpara: the contents of the entry as a string

refsect2.para: The get_text() method returns the value of the "text" property which is a string containing the contents of the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_text_length

listitem.simpara: the current number of characters in GtkEntry, or 0 if there are none.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.14 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_text_length() method retrieves the current length of the text in entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_layout

listitem.simpara: the pango.Layout for this entry

refsect2.para: The get_layout() method gets the pango.Layout used to display the entry. The layout is useful to e.g. convert text positions to pixel positions, in combination with get_layout_offsets().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_layout_offsets

listitem.simpara: a tuple containing the X and Y offsets of the pango layout

refsect2.para: The get_layout_offsets() method obtains the position of the pango.Layout used to render text in the entry, in widget coordinates and returns it as a tuple. This method is used to line up the text in an entry with some other text, e.g. when using the entry to implement editable cells in a sheet widget. It is also useful to convert mouse events into coordinates inside the pango.Layout, e.g. to take some action if some part of the entry text is clicked.
Note that as the user scrolls around in the entry the offsets will change; you'll need to connect to the "notify::scroll_offset" signal to track this.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_alignment

listitem.simpara: The horizontal alignment ranging from 0.0 to 1.0 representing the freespace to the left (right for RTL layouts) of the text.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.4 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_alignment() method sets the "xalign" property to the value of xalign. The alignment controls the horizontal positioning of the contents when the displayed text is shorter than the width of the entry. The value of xalign is the fraction of freespace to the left (right in RTL layouts) of the text.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_alignment

listitem.simpara: The horizontal alignment ranging from 0.0 to 1.0 representing the freespace to the left (right for RTL layouts) of the text.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.4 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_alignment() method returns the value of the "xalign" property which is the fraction of freespace (if any) to the left (right in RTL layouts) of the text.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_completion

listitem.simpara: a gtk.EntryCompletion

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.4 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_completion() method sets the gtk.EntryCompletion specified by completion to be the auxiliary completion object to use with the entry. All further configuration of the completion mechanism is done using completion and the gtk.EntryCompletion methods.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_completion

listitem.simpara: the auxiliary completion object

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.4 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_completion() method returns the gtk.EntryCompletion object currently in use by the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_inner_border

listitem.simpara: a gtk.Border, or None

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.10 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_inner_border() method sets the entry's "inner-border" property to the value specified by border, or clears it if None is passed. The "inner-border" is the area around the entry's text, but inside its frame.

If set, this property overrides the inner-border style property. Overriding the style-provided border is useful when you want to do in-place editing of some text in a canvas or list widget, where pixel-exact positioning of the entry is important.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_inner_border

listitem.simpara: the entry's gtk.Border, or None if none was set.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.10 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_inner_border() method returns the value of the entry's "inner-border" property. See set_inner_border() for more information.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_cursor_hadjustment

listitem.simpara: An adjustment which should be adjusted when the cursor is moved, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.12 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_cursor_hadjustment() method hooks up an adjustment to the cursor position in an entry, so that when the cursor is moved, the adjustment is scrolled to show that position. See gtk.ScrolledWindow.get_hadjustment for a typical way of obtaining the adjustment. The adjustment has to be in pixel units and in the same coordinate system as the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_cursor_hadjustment

listitem.simpara: The horizontal cursor adjustment, or None if none has been set.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.12 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_cursor_hadjustment() method retrieves the horizontal cursor adjustment for the entry. See set_cursor_hadjustment.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_overwrite_mode

listitem.simpara: new value.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.14 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_overwrite_mode() method sets whether the text is overwritten when typing in the Entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_overwrite_mode

listitem.simpara: whether text is overwritten when typing in the Entry.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.14 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_overwrite_mode() method gets the value set by gtk.Entry.set_overwrite_mode().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_buffer

listitem.simpara: a gtk.EntryBuffer.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_buffer() method sets the gtk.EntryBuffer object which holds the text for this widget.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_buffer

listitem.simpara: a gtk.EntryBuffer object.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_buffer() method gets the gtk.EntryBuffer which holds the text for this widget.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_progress_fraction

listitem.simpara: fraction of the task that's been completed.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_progress_fraction() method causes the entry's progress indicator to "fill in" the given fraction of the bar. The fraction should be between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_progress_fraction

listitem.simpara: a fraction from 0.0 to 1.0.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_progress_fraction() method returns the current fraction of the task that's been completed. See gtk.Entry.set_progress_fraction().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_progress_pulse_step

listitem.simpara: fraction between 0.0 and 1.0.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_progress_pulse_step() method sets the fraction of total entry width to move the progress bouncing block for each call to gtk.Entry.progress_pulse().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_progress_pulse_step

listitem.simpara: a fraction from 0.0 to 1.0.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_progress_pulse_step() method retrieves the pulse step set with gtk.Entry.set_progress_pulse_step().

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.progress_pulse

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The progress_pulse() method indicates that some progress is made, but you don't know how much. Causes the entry's progress indicator to enter "activity mode," where a block bounces back and forth. Each call to gtk.Entry.progress_pulse() causes the block to move by a little bit (the amount of movement per pulse is determined by gtk.Entry.set_progress_pulse_step()).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_from_pixbuf

listitem.simpara: The position at which to set the icon.
A gtk.gdk.Pixbuf, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_from_pixbuf() method sets the icon shown in the specified position using a pixbuf.
If pixbuf is None, no icon will be shown in the specified position.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_from_stock

listitem.simpara: The position at which to set the icon.
The name of the stock item, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_from_stock() method sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from a stock image.
If stock_id is None, no icon will be shown in the specified position.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_from_icon_name

listitem.simpara: The position at which to set the icon.
An icon name, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_from_icon_name() method sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from the current icon theme.
If icon_name is None, no icon will be shown in the specified position.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_from_gicon

listitem.simpara: The position at which to set the icon.
The icon to set, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_from_gicon() method sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from the current icon theme. If the icon isn't known, a "broken image" icon will be displayed instead.
If icon is None, no icon will be shown in the specified position.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_storage_type

listitem.simpara: Icon position.
the image representation being used.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_storage_type() method gets the type of representation being used by the icon to store image data. If the icon has no image data, the return value will be gtk.IMAGE_EMPTY.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_pixbuf

listitem.simpara: Icon position.
A gtk.gdk.Pixbuf, or None if no icon is set for this position.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_pixbuf() method retrieves the image used for the icon.
Unlike the other methods of setting and getting icon data, this method will work regardless of whether the icon was set using a gtk.gdk.Pixbuf, a gio.Icon, a stock item, or an icon name.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_stock

listitem.simpara: Icon position.
A stock id, or None if no icon is set or if the icon wasn't set from a stock id.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_stock() method retrieves the stock id used for the icon, or None if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g. by pixbuf, icon name or gicon).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_name

listitem.simpara: Icon position.
An icon name, or None if no icon is set or if the icon wasn't set from an icon name.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_name() method retrieves the icon name used for the icon, or None if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g. by pixbuf, stock or gicon).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_gicon

listitem.simpara: Icon position.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_gicon() method retrieves the gio.Icon used for the icon, or None if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g. by stock, pixbuf, or icon name).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_activatable

refsect2.para: The set_icon_activatable() method sets whether the icon is activatable.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_activatable

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_sensitive

listitem.simpara: Icon position.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_sensitive() method returns whether the icon appears sensitive or insensitive. .

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_at_pos

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_text

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_tooltip_text

listitem.simpara: the icon position.
the tooltip text, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_tooltip_text() method gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_markup

listitem.simpara: the icon position.
the contents of the tooltip for the icon, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_tooltip_markup() method sets tooltip as the contents of the tooltip for the icon at the specified position. tooltip is assumed to be marked up with the Pango text markup language.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_tooltip_markup

listitem.simpara: the icon position.
the tooltip text, or None.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_tooltip_markup() method gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in the entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.set_icon_drag_source

listitem.simpara: icon position.
the targets (data formats) in which the data can be provided.
a bitmask of the allowed drag actions.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_icon_drag_source() method sets up the icon at the given position so that GTK+ will start a drag operation when the user clicks and drags the icon.

To handle the drag operation, you need to connect to the usual "drag-data-get" (or possibly "drag-data-delete") signal, and use gtk.Entry.get_current_icon_drag_source()) in your signal handler to find out if the drag was started from an icon.

By default, GTK+ uses the icon as the drag icon. You can use the "drag-begin" signal to set a different icon. Note that you have to use gobject.connect_after() to ensure that your signal handler gets executed after the default handler.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_current_icon_drag_source

listitem.simpara: the index of the icon which is the source of the current DND operation, or -1.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.16 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_current_icon_drag_source() method returns the index of the icon which is the source of the current DND operation, or -1.
This function is meant to be used in a "drag-data-get" callback.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_icon_window

listitem.simpara: Icon position.
the entry's icon window at icon_pos.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_icon_window() method returns the gtk.gdk.Window which contains the entry's icon at icon_pos. This function is useful when drawing something to the entry in an "expose-event" callback because it enables the callback to distinguish between the text window and entry's icon windows.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.get_text_window

listitem.simpara: the entry's text window.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_text_window() method returns the gtk.gdk.Window which contains the text. This function is useful when drawing something to the entry in an "expose-event" callback because it enables the callback to distinguish between the text window and entry's icon windows.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.layout_index_to_text_index

listitem.simpara: index of the entry layout text.
index of the entry contents.

refsect2.para: The layout_index_to_text_index() method converts from a position in the entry contents (returned by gtk.Entry.get_text()) to a position in the entry's pango.Layout (returned by gtk.Entry.get_layout(), with text retrieved via pango.Layout.get_text()).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.text_index_to_layout_index

listitem.simpara: index of the entry contents.
index of the entry layout text.

refsect2.para: The text_index_to_layout_index() method converts from a position in the entry contents (returned by gtk.Entry.get_text()) to a position in the entry's pango.Layout (returned by gtk.Entry.get_layout(), with text retrieved via pango.Layout.get_text()).

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.im_context_filter_keypress

listitem.simpara: The key event.

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The im_context_filter_keypress() method allows the gtk.Entry input method to internally handle key press and release events. If this function returns True, then no further processing should be done for this key event. See gtk.IMContext.filter_keypress().

Note that you are expected to call this function from your handler when overriding key event handling. This is needed in the case when you need to insert your own key handling between the input method and the default key event handling of the gtk.Entry.

refsect2.title: gtk.Entry.reset_im_context

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.22 and above.

refsect2.para: The reset_im_context() method resets the input method context of the entry if needed.
This can be necessary in the case where modifying the buffer would confuse on-going input method behavior.

refsect2.title: The "delete-from-cursor" gtk.Entry Signal

listitem.simpara: the entry that received the signal
the type of deletion
the number of deletions of the type to perform
the first user parameter (if any) specified with the connect() method
additional user parameters (if any)

refsect2.para: The "delete-from-cursor" signal is emitted when the a deletion from the cursor i.e. removal o text at the cursor position, either before it (negative count) or after it (positive count). The value of delete_type can be one of:

listitem.simpara: gtk.DELETE_CHARS
gtk.DELETE_WORD_ENDS
gtk.DELETE_WORDS
gtk.DELETE_DISPLAY_LINES
gtk.DELETE_DISPLAY_LINE_ENDS
gtk.DELETE_PARAGRAPH_ENDS
gtk.DELETE_PARAGRAPHS
gtk.DELETE_WHITESPACE

refsect2.title: The "move-cursor" gtk.Entry Signal

listitem.simpara: the entry that received the signal
the size of the step to move the cursor
the number of steps to move the cursor
if True extend the selection as well as moving the cursor
the first user parameter (if any) specified with the connect() method
additional user parameters (if any)

refsect2.para: The "move-cursor" signal is emitted when the cursor is being moved by count steps of size step. If extend_selection is True the selection is extended as the cursor is being moved. The value of step can be one of:

listitem.simpara: gtk.MOVEMENT_LOGICAL_POSITIONS
gtk.MOVEMENT_VISUAL_POSITIONS
gtk.MOVEMENT_WORDS
gtk.MOVEMENT_DISPLAY_LINES
gtk.MOVEMENT_DISPLAY_LINE_ENDS
gtk.MOVEMENT_PARAGRAPH_ENDS
gtk.MOVEMENT_PARAGRAPHS
gtk.MOVEMENT_PAGES
gtk.MOVEMENT_BUFFER_ENDS

refsect2.title: The "preedit-changed" gtk.Entry Signal

listitem.simpara: the entry that received the signal
the current preedit string
the first user parameter (if any) specified with the connect() method
additional user parameters (if any)

refsect2.para: The "preedit-changed" signal is emitted when an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.
